pullrequest.title: Expanding the functionality of the plugin framework, and introducing PluginPtr and specializations

content.raw:
I really like the improvements to the plugin system. There's a lot of great stuff, C++ warning suppression cross platform, supporting multiple plugins per library, supporting multiple interfaces per plugin, fixing bugs related to plugin interface casting when using multiple inheritance, etc.

I'm having a lot of trouble understanding it all when combined with the addition of `PluginPtr` and `SpecializedPluginPtr`. After a few days  worth of reviewing this PR I'm still not confident I understand everything.  Of course you don't have to, but would you be willing to make the `PluginPtr` and `SpecializedPluginPtr` a separate PR?If that sounds OK I removed them in the branch `PluginPtrSemantics_minus_ctrp`. It removes a net of 1700 lines of code.

It seems like `SpecializedPluginPtr` has a very specific task: fast access to interfaces (after a one-time construction cost) using templates without using RTTI. However the code changes it needs seem to go very deep. Is is it possible to implement `SpecializedPluginPtr` in a way that it is more self contained?

For example, `SpecializedPlutinPtr` uses the map inside the `Plugin` class implementation, which means `Plugin` implementation is aware of it in that it has code to avoid invalidating map keys. How about `SpecializedPluginPtr` using iterators to a map that it owns instead?

Another example is`SpecializedPluginPtr` inherits from `Plugin`, but it really shadows those methods and uses some template magic to switch between `SpecializedPlugin<I>` and `Plugin` and . How about switch between `std::shared_ptr<Plugin>` and `SpecializedPluginPtr *`? If this is possible it means a `SpecializedPluginPtr`could be created from just a shared pointer.
content.html:
I really like the improvements to the plugin system. There's a lot of great stuff, C++ warning suppression cross platform, supporting multiple plugins per library, supporting multiple interfaces per plugin, fixing bugs related to plugin interface casting when using multiple inheritance, etc.

I'm having a lot of trouble understanding it all when combined with the addition of PluginPtr and SpecializedPluginPtr. After a few days worth of reviewing this PR I'm still not confident I understand everything. Of course you don't have to, but would you be willing to make the PluginPtr and SpecializedPluginPtr a separate PR?If that sounds OK I removed them in the branch PluginPtrSemantics_minus_ctrp. It removes a net of 1700 lines of code.

It seems like SpecializedPluginPtr has a very specific task: fast access to interfaces (after a one-time construction cost) using templates without using RTTI. However the code changes it needs seem to go very deep. Is is it possible to implement SpecializedPluginPtr in a way that it is more self contained?

For example, SpecializedPlutinPtr uses the map inside the Plugin class implementation, which means Plugin implementation is aware of it in that it has code to avoid invalidating map keys. How about SpecializedPluginPtr using iterators to a map that it owns instead?

Another example isSpecializedPluginPtr inherits from Plugin, but it really shadows those methods and uses some template magic to switch between SpecializedPlugin<I> and Plugin and . How about switch between std::shared_ptr<Plugin> and SpecializedPluginPtr *? If this is possible it means a SpecializedPluginPtrcould be created from just a shared pointer.

pullrequest.title: Expanding the functionality of the plugin framework, and introducing PluginPtr and specializations

content.raw: what is this?
content.html: what is this?

pullrequest.title: Expanding the functionality of the plugin framework, and introducing PluginPtr and specializations

content.raw:
Template magic.

But more seriously, it's a placeholder template class which allows us to define overloaded versions of the functions `PrivateXXXSpecInterface(~)` where `XXX` is `Get` or `Has`. One overload (the non-templated one) will be called when `XXX<Interface>()` is called and `Interface` matches `SpecInterface`, and that will be the high-performance version of the function. The other overload is called when `Interface` does not match `SpecInterface`, and that will redirect to the normal performance version of the function.

This allows users to call `Get<T>()` or `Has<T>()`, and they'll opaquely get high performance when available and normal performance otherwise, automatically.
content.html:
Template magic.

But more seriously, it's a placeholder template class which allows us to define overloaded versions of the functions PrivateXXXSpecInterface(~) where XXX is Get or Has. One overload (the non-templated one) will be called when XXX<Interface>() is called and Interface matches SpecInterface, and that will be the high-performance version of the function. The other overload is called when Interface does not match SpecInterface, and that will redirect to the normal performance version of the function.

This allows users to call Get<T>() or Has<T>(), and they'll opaquely get high performance when available and normal performance otherwise, automatically.

content.raw:
there's only a few places left in [PluginLoader](https://codecov.io/bb/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/src/PluginPtrSemantics/src/PluginLoader.cc) that don't have test coverage. In 3362306 (branch `PluginPtrSemantics_instantiate_unloaded_plugin`), I improve the PluginLoader test coverage by trying to Instantiate a plugin that hasn't yet been loaded and verify that the returned pointer is null. There wasn't a console error message about this, so I added one in 00de9d66e0b3.

Please consider merging with this branch.
content.html:
there's only a few places left in PluginLoader that don't have test coverage. In 3362306 (branch PluginPtrSemantics_instantiate_unloaded_plugin), I improve the PluginLoader test coverage by trying to Instantiate a plugin that hasn't yet been loaded and verify that the returned pointer is null. There wasn't a console error message about this, so I added one in 00de9d66e0b3.

Please consider merging with this branch.

pullrequest.title: Expanding the functionality of the plugin framework, and introducing PluginPtr and specializations

content.raw: Just checking that you do want to return a reference to a shared pointer. Returning a reference does not modify the shared pointer's reference counter.
content.html: Just checking that you do want to return a reference to a shared pointer. Returning a reference does not modify the shared pointer's reference counter.

pullrequest.title: Expanding the functionality of the plugin framework, and introducing PluginPtr and specializations

content.raw: Yep, that's exactly why I want to return by reference instead of value. It's returning a reference to a member variable that is held inside of the `Plugin` object, so its reference count will already be greater than zero even as we return it by reference. If the reference ultimately doesn't get used, then we'll have avoided an unnecessary increment+decrement.
content.html: Yep, that's exactly why I want to return by reference instead of value. It's returning a reference to a member variable that is held inside of the Plugin object, so its reference count will already be greater than zero even as we return it by reference. If the reference ultimately doesn't get used, then we'll have avoided an unnecessary increment+decrement.

pullrequest.title: Expanding the functionality of the plugin framework, and introducing PluginPtr and specializations

content.raw: Is the hash meant to be unique?
content.html: Is the hash meant to be unique?

pullrequest.title: Expanding the functionality of the plugin framework, and introducing PluginPtr and specializations

content.raw:
This hash function piggybacks on the STL implementation of hashing for `std::shared_ptr`. It's not guaranteed to be unique, but it probably will be most of the time.

The real purpose of this function is so that `PluginPtr` can be stored in a `std::unordered_set` or used as a key in a `std::unordered_map`. Maybe it's worth mentioning that in the header documentation.
content.html:
This hash function piggybacks on the STL implementation of hashing for std::shared_ptr. It's not guaranteed to be unique, but it probably will be most of the time.

The real purpose of this function is so that PluginPtr can be stored in a std::unordered_set or used as a key in a std::unordered_map. Maybe it's worth mentioning that in the header documentation.

content.raw: Small suggestion. As an example, an empty string is still a valid string. Here I think you're using "empty" to indicate whether a pointer is valid or invalid. How about "IsInvalid", or "IsNull"?
content.html: Small suggestion. As an example, an empty string is still a valid string. Here I think you're using "empty" to indicate whether a pointer is valid or invalid. How about "IsInvalid", or "IsNull"?

pullrequest.title: Expanding the functionality of the plugin framework, and introducing PluginPtr and specializations

content.raw:
I think the string idea is a perfect analogy here. The `Plugin` object is still a valid object, just as an empty `std::string` is valid: you can use its functions, there just isn't anything inside of it. In the case of a `Plugin`, you can query for interfaces, it'll just always return a `nullptr`.

Maybe I should rephrase the documentation to avoid using the word "valid".
content.html:
I think the string idea is a perfect analogy here. The Plugin object is still a valid object, just as an empty std::string is valid: you can use its functions, there just isn't anything inside of it. In the case of a Plugin, you can query for interfaces, it'll just always return a nullptr.

Maybe I should rephrase the documentation to avoid using the word "valid".

pullrequest.title: Expanding the functionality of the plugin framework, and introducing PluginPtr and specializations

content.raw:
Users can freely use `SpecializedPlugin`. The doxygen comment here is specifically for the `template <class... OtherSpecInterfaces>` specialization, which exists as a formality because the syntax of variadic templates is weird.

The gist of the comment is that users should look at the documentation for specialization that comes after this one if they want to see a proper explanation of `SpecializedPlugin`. I'll try to think about how to make this comment more clear.
content.html:
Users can freely use SpecializedPlugin. The doxygen comment here is specifically for the template <class... OtherSpecInterfaces> specialization, which exists as a formality because the syntax of variadic templates is weird.

The gist of the comment is that users should look at the documentation for specialization that comes after this one if they want to see a proper explanation of SpecializedPlugin. I'll try to think about how to make this comment more clear.

pullrequest.title: Expanding the functionality of the plugin framework, and introducing PluginPtr and specializations

content.raw:
Are you imagining that "plugin instance" refers to the library rather than the plugin object? Qt's terminology and `ign-common`'s terminology differ in this respect.

In Qt's plugin framework the word "plugin" refers to a library, whereas in `ign-common` (as well as `class_loader`), the word "plugin" refers to a class instance that has been loaded. I think "delete" (or maybe "destruct") is the most idiomatic term when referring to a class instance that is being destructed.

I'll definitely think about how to explain this better. In particular, I'd like to come up with a better term than "plugin instance" when referring to class instances that have been loaded.
content.html:
Are you imagining that "plugin instance" refers to the library rather than the plugin object? Qt's terminology and ign-common's terminology differ in this respect.

In Qt's plugin framework the word "plugin" refers to a library, whereas in ign-common (as well as class_loader), the word "plugin" refers to a class instance that has been loaded. I think "delete" (or maybe "destruct") is the most idiomatic term when referring to a class instance that is being destructed.

I'll definitely think about how to explain this better. In particular, I'd like to come up with a better term than "plugin instance" when referring to class instances that have been loaded.

content.raw:
Just a slight detail which confused me for a second. We've been using `dataPtr` across ignition libraries when using the pimpl pattern, but even though the usage is similar here, the semantics are slightly different, right? 

I'm fine with it the way it is, but I'd like to point it out in case other people run into the same confusion.
content.html:

pullrequest.title: Expanding the functionality of the plugin framework, and introducing PluginPtr and specializations

content.raw: Yeah, that's a fair point. I think I originally intended to use our usual `dataPtr` pattern here, but then I realized that it didn't make sense to put anything in it besides the `PluginType` instance, so some wires got crossed on the naming. I'll come up with a better name to give this field.
content.html: Yeah, that's a fair point. I think I originally intended to use our usual dataPtr pattern here, but then I realized that it didn't make sense to put anything in it besides the PluginType instance, so some wires got crossed on the naming. I'll come up with a better name to give this field.

pullrequest.title: Expanding the functionality of the plugin framework, and introducing PluginPtr and specializations

content.raw: Would this constructor still work if `std::is_same<PluginType, OtherPluginType>::value == true`? That is, can the copy constructor above be deleted?
content.html: Would this constructor still work if std::is_same<PluginType, OtherPluginType>::value == true? That is, can the copy constructor above be deleted?

pullrequest.title: Expanding the functionality of the plugin framework, and introducing PluginPtr and specializations

content.raw:
C++ has an idiosyncrasy where it refuses to consider a templated constructor to be a "copy constructor" and will create a default copy constructor (or implicitly delete the copy constructor), even if a templated constructor would make a perfectly suitable copy constructor.

As a consequence, if `OtherPluginType` is equivalent to `PluginType`, then this templated constructor will not be considered at all during overload resolution, because the compiler will only be willing to use the copy constructor in that scenario. Therefore, if we throw away our custom definition of the copy constructor, then it would use the default copy constructor in that scenario, which would result in incorrect behavior.
content.html:
C++ has an idiosyncrasy where it refuses to consider a templated constructor to be a "copy constructor" and will create a default copy constructor (or implicitly delete the copy constructor), even if a templated constructor would make a perfectly suitable copy constructor.

As a consequence, if OtherPluginType is equivalent to PluginType, then this templated constructor will not be considered at all during overload resolution, because the compiler will only be willing to use the copy constructor in that scenario. Therefore, if we throw away our custom definition of the copy constructor, then it would use the default copy constructor in that scenario, which would result in incorrect behavior.

content.raw:
I've been having trouble reading the code where these functions are used. It may be due to the information that matters being deep inside the name `Private[important bit]SpecInterface(`. How about renaming these methods to `Interface *Get(type<interface>)` and `bool Has(type<SpecInterface>)`?

Also I like that it might be a loophole in the style guide - `Get` isn't a prefix, it's the whole name!
content.html:
I've been having trouble reading the code where these functions are used. It may be due to the information that matters being deep inside the name Private[important bit]SpecInterface(. How about renaming these methods to Interface *Get(type<interface>) and bool Has(type<SpecInterface>)?

Also I like that it might be a loophole in the style guide - Get isn't a prefix, it's the whole name!

pullrequest.title: Expanding the functionality of the plugin framework, and introducing PluginPtr and specializations

content.raw: Or could it be `QueryInterface(type<interface>)` and `HasInterface(type<interface>)`? That would make it more clear what these private methods are used for.
content.html: Or could it be QueryInterface(type<interface>) and HasInterface(type<interface>)? That would make it more clear what these private methods are used for.

pullrequest.title: Expanding the functionality of the plugin framework, and introducing PluginPtr and specializations

content.raw:
I totally agree that readability is important, so I'm definitely open to changing these functions names.

The reason I made the names messy like this is to rigidly separate them from the public API functions, so end-users will naturally gaze past them and not confuse them with the public API functions that they're supposed to be using.

My main concern with calling them `QueryInterface(type<Interface>)` is that we'd be overloading the `QueryInterface` function with a mix of public and private functions. This isn't technically a wrong thing to do, but I think it can be confusing for end-users (especially when they're using an IDE with autocomplete), and they might waste time trying to understand what this silly `type<Interface>` argument is, even though they never need to touch that or even think about it.

How would you feel about `PrivateQueryInterface(type<Interface>)`? That way, we'd make the tie between the public API and private implementation functions more clear without overloading them.
content.html:
I totally agree that readability is important, so I'm definitely open to changing these functions names.

The reason I made the names messy like this is to rigidly separate them from the public API functions, so end-users will naturally gaze past them and not confuse them with the public API functions that they're supposed to be using.

My main concern with calling them QueryInterface(type<Interface>) is that we'd be overloading the QueryInterface function with a mix of public and private functions. This isn't technically a wrong thing to do, but I think it can be confusing for end-users (especially when they're using an IDE with autocomplete), and they might waste time trying to understand what this silly type<Interface> argument is, even though they never need to touch that or even think about it.

How would you feel about PrivateQueryInterface(type<Interface>)? That way, we'd make the tie between the public API and private implementation functions more clear without overloading them.

pullrequest.title: Expanding the functionality of the plugin framework, and introducing PluginPtr and specializations

content.raw:
`PrivateQueryInterface` Looks fine to me.

I see that avoiding user confusion has been made a priority. Given that access specifiers are before everything and all the private methods are grouped into a code block that calls out `--- Private API ---`, I would be surprised if a user reading the header got confused. Does Qt Creator autocomplete functions with a `private` access specifier?
content.html:
PrivateQueryInterface Looks fine to me.

I see that avoiding user confusion has been made a priority. Given that access specifiers are before everything and all the private methods are grouped into a code block that calls out --- Private API ---, I would be surprised if a user reading the header got confused. Does Qt Creator autocomplete functions with a private access specifier?

pullrequest.title: Expanding the functionality of the plugin framework, and introducing PluginPtr and specializations

content.raw: Every IDE autocomplete that I can remember working with (Qt, CLion, and Visual Studio) will show a list of all overloads for a function, both the public and the private versions. There is usually some icon next to the function name to indicate whether it's public or private, but that icon is easy to overlook, and just the existence of multiple overloads for the function could throw users off.
content.html: Every IDE autocomplete that I can remember working with (Qt, CLion, and Visual Studio) will show a list of all overloads for a function, both the public and the private versions. There is usually some icon next to the function name to indicate whether it's public or private, but that icon is easy to overlook, and just the existence of multiple overloads for the function could throw users off.

pullrequest.title: Expanding the functionality of the plugin framework, and introducing PluginPtr and specializations

content.raw: Just curious, why does this work with `bool specialized` but not `true` as the second template parameter?
content.html: Just curious, why does this work with bool specialized but not true as the second template parameter?

pullrequest.title: Expanding the functionality of the plugin framework, and introducing PluginPtr and specializations

content.raw: This is an awkward C++ template syntax thing. This class declaration+definition provides a default implementation, and then the next one provides a specialized implementation for `false`. Since a bool can only be `true` or `false`, this default will only be used when `specialized` is `true`, so it provides both a "default" implementation and a "specialized" implementation for the `true` case.
content.html: This is an awkward C++ template syntax thing. This class declaration+definition provides a default implementation, and then the next one provides a specialized implementation for false. Since a bool can only be true or false, this default will only be used when specialized is true, so it provides both a "default" implementation and a "specialized" implementation for the true case.

pullrequest.title: Expanding the functionality of the plugin framework, and introducing PluginPtr and specializations

content.raw: What are the operators `<`, `>`, `<=`, and `>=` used by? Is it a requirement to be put into some container?
content.html: What are the operators <, >, <=, and >= used by? Is it a requirement to be put into some container?

pullrequest.title: Expanding the functionality of the plugin framework, and introducing PluginPtr and specializations

content.raw:
The principle motivation is so that this class satisfies the concept of a smart pointer.

In most cases, `<` and `==` are the only ones that are required to use this pointer type in most C++ STL containers, but we may as well provide all of them for the sake of completeness.

In a better world, we could've just provided a [spaceship operator](http://open-std.org/JTC1/SC22/WG21/docs/papers/2017/p0515r0.pdf).
content.html:
The principle motivation is so that this class satisfies the concept of a smart pointer.

In most cases, < and == are the only ones that are required to use this pointer type in most C++ STL containers, but we may as well provide all of them for the sake of completeness.

In a better world, we could've just provided a spaceship operator.

pullrequest.title: Expanding the functionality of the plugin framework, and introducing PluginPtr and specializations

content.html:
What happens if the assignment operator is used after insertion?

PluginPtr p1 = ...;
PluginPtr p2 = ...;

std::set<ignition::common::PluginPtr> orderedSet;
orderedSet.insert(p1);
auto p2Iter = orderedSet.insert(p2);

// Two elements in a set with the same hash?
*p2Iter = p1;

pullrequest.title: Expanding the functionality of the plugin framework, and introducing PluginPtr and specializations

content.raw:
This is effectively the same question as having a `std::set<std::shared_ptr<T>>`.

The answer is that (as of C++11), both `std::set<T>::iterator` and `std::set<T>::const_iterator` are identical "Constant Bidirectional Iterators", so dereferencing them produces a const-reference to the key value. Since the reference is const-qualified, the compiler will prevent that assignment operator from being used.
content.html:
This is effectively the same question as having a std::set<std::shared_ptr<T>>.

The answer is that (as of C++11), both std::set<T>::iterator and std::set<T>::const_iterator are identical "Constant Bidirectional Iterators", so dereferencing them produces a const-reference to the key value. Since the reference is const-qualified, the compiler will prevent that assignment operator from being used.

pullrequest.title: Expanding the functionality of the plugin framework, and introducing PluginPtr and specializations

content.raw:
Needing 50 iterations is strange. It doesn't seem like the content of the registers should matter since the test is in a non-inlined function. The calling convention is going to set all of the registers the same for each test.

It could be a cache miss, though just one warm up should be good enough.
content.html:
Needing 50 iterations is strange. It doesn't seem like the content of the registers should matter since the test is in a non-inlined function. The calling convention is going to set all of the registers the same for each test.

It could be a cache miss, though just one warm up should be good enough.

pullrequest.title: Expanding the functionality of the plugin framework, and introducing PluginPtr and specializations

content.raw: The choice of 50 iterations was based on experimentation. Having significantly less than that was producing inconsistent benchmark results. I'm totally open to making changes to this test, though.
content.html: The choice of 50 iterations was based on experimentation. Having significantly less than that was producing inconsistent benchmark results. I'm totally open to making changes to this test, though.
